acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "solid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

carcinogenicity.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as Category D by EPA (1993), Group 3 (SELENIUM AND SELENIUM COMPOUNDS) by IARC (1987).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available

explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_solids.rationale: Selenium dioxide (SeO2), the anhydride of selenious acid, is classified as non-flammable according to ICSC (2004)

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale:
No data available
As for the health hazards, refer to "ID1063, Sodium Selenite, CAS: 10102-18-8."

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data, though being inorganic compounds containing oxygen

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Selenium dioxide (SeO2), the anhydride of selenious acid, is classified as non-flammable according to ICSC (2004)

reproductive_toxicity.rationale:
Classification not possible in the absence of data on reproductive toxicity. The results of teratogenicity studies with rats, mice, rabbits, hamsters, and crab-eating macaques suggest no evidence of malformation up to doses inducing parental toxicity, described in CERI Hazard Data 2001-39(2) (2002).
As for the health hazards, refer to "ID1063, Sodium Selenite, CAS: 10102-18-8."

self_heating_substances.rationale: Selenium dioxide (SeO2), the anhydride of selenious acid, is classified as non-flammable according to ICSC (2004)

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive or self-reactive properties

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in ICSC (J) (2000) of the human health effects: "Corrosive to the eye, skin and respiratory tract."

skin_corrosion_irritation.hazard_statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in EHC 58 (1986) of the human health effects: "Selenious acid, which is readily deliquescent, burns the skin when in contact with moisture on the skin from sweating." The substance is thus considered corrosive to the skin, though the severity of the effects is unknown. Although classified into Category 1A-1C, it should be placed in Category 1A from the viewpoint of safety if further subclassification is needed.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement:
Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (nervous system)
May cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (respiratory system, liver)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence including "vomiting, dizziness, dysosmia" (CERI Hazard Data 2001-39(2) (2002)), "nasal hypersensitivity, persistent garlic-like smell, hypersensitiveness, tissue damage and liver damage" (ICSC (J) (2000)). The effects on the respiratory organs and liver are classified into Category 2 since the priority rating of the referenced study is 2.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale:
Insufficient data available

The acute toxicity of inorganic selenium compounds manifests in humans as "clinical findings including vomiting, diarrhea, laboured breathing, weakness, unstable gait, coma; histological findings including pulmonary edema, necrosis of the liver, degeneration of the skeletal muscles, renal tubular hydropic degeneration, swelling and rupture of the myocardial mitochondria" (PATTY (4th, 2000)).
